Title5: How is Consumer Privacy and Internet Freedom in United States?
Section5: Key consumer privacy and internet freedom laws in the United States include the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA). The personal data law sets strict rules on the processing and storage of data of Russian citizens, requiring data to be stored on servers physically located in Russia. The Yarovaya Law, implemented in 2016, requires internet service providers to store communications data for six months and metadata for up to three years. In addition, the Federal Service for Supervision of Communications (Roskomnadzor) has broad powers to block online content and monitor compliance with these regulations, leading to criticism that it restricts internet freedom and user privacy.
